text.content:
Welcome to the Stress module.

The purpose of this module is to provide you with basic knowledge about the biology of stress and the impact of stress on parent-child interactions.

Parents often believe children are too young to experience stress, yet stress is part of everyday life, even for babies and toddlers. The ability to manage stress is built into specific brain functions and begins early in life.

Educator Training Goals:

Identify the three types of stress that affect the developing child.

Explain the impact of repeated, long-term stress on children.

Explain how parental support and involvement helps to regulate a young child's stress response.

Communicate the importance of teaching parents the role that stress plays in a young child's social and emotional development.

Help parents learn to identify their own stress.

graphic.notes: Ready to Feel 3 from Stress folder in Physical Dev.

audio.transcript: Welcome to the Stress module. The purpose of this module is to provide you with basic knowledge about the biology of stress and the impact of stress on parent-child interactions.

Parents often believe children are too young to experience stress, yet stress is part of everyday life, even for babies and toddlers. The ability to manage stress is built into specific brain functions and begins early in life.

After completing this module, you will be able to 1) Identify the three types of stress that affect the developing child. 2) Explain the impact of repeated, long-term stress on children. 3) Explain how parental support and involvement helps to regulate a young child's stress response. 4) Communicate the importance of teaching parents the role that stress plays in a young child's social and emotional development. And 5) Help parents learn to identify their own stress. To begin, click a Topic in the bottom menu.

text.content:

Much of the discussion around self-regulation encourages parents to notice and respond to their child's emotions. Pillar 2 of the Parenting Counts Program addresses social-emotional development and teaches skills for Emotion Coaching.

This is a good opportunity to create anticipation regarding the upcoming topics and let participants know when you will cover this material with them.
